title: Secondary Schools - Best Senior Secondary School in Dubai Near You
content: Secondary Schools - Best Senior Secondary School in Dubai Near You Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login About Principal‚Äôs Message Mission, Vision, Values A Positive Education School Leadership Academic Results Inspection Reports Our Achievements Sunmarke Alumni Wellbeing The Achievement Centre ‚Äì Inclusion Department Our Campus Learning Nursery Our Approach Enriched Learning EYFS Our Approach Early Years Curriculum Enriched Learning Primary Our Approach Primary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Student Council and Ambassadors Secondary Our Approach Secondary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Sunmarke Mini MBA Student Council and Ambassadors Sixth Form Our Approach A-Levels BTECs IB Diploma Programme (IBDP) Student Enrichment Coding CIVITAS Careers Counsellor Student Leadership Signature Programmes STEAM & Design Thinking Environment & Sustainability University & Career Readiness Programme Fortes Pro Sports Academy Positive Education Global Language Academy Financial Literacy Programme Enterprise & Mini-MBA Programme Communications, Media & the Performing Arts Programme Admissions Apply Online Schedule a Visit Tuition Fees Scholarships Re-enrol Online School Forms FAQs For Parents School Uniform School Timings Academic Calendar School Events Calendar Policies Transport Services Dining & Catering Sports Hub Parent Engagement Governance Committee Activities Sunmarke Free Extracurricular Activities (ECAs) Sunmarke Paid Extracurricular Activities Third-Party Paid Extracurricular Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login Secondary Curriculum Learning > Secondary > Secondary Curriculum Secondary School Secondary Curriculum Subject Offerings Rooted in STEAM ( Science, Technology, Engineering, Art & Mathematics) and Creative Learning Our innovative curriculum prepares students to make the right choices in Year 10. As an inclusive school, Sunmarke offers a wide range of options at Key Stage 4. Through offering GCSE, IGCSE, and BTEC courses, we are able to accommodate a wide range of learning styles, whilst ensuring the level of challenge is such that all post-16 pathways remain open to students. GCSE examinations are the mainstay of an English education, with most students following this pathway. At Sunmarke we also offer IGCSE examinations; the ‚ÄòI‚Äô stands for international and means the course has been adapted to suit a more international student body. The difficulty level of GCSE and IGCSE exams are the same, but the content of GCSE examinations is more English-centred. A good example of this would be in Business Studies where the case studies for a GCSE would be UK companies, which many of our students would not have heard of. This is why we follow the IGCSE pathway for Business Studies, meaning the case studies focus on large multi-national companies all our students would know. BTEC courses are as challenging as GCSE course but are assessed in a different manner. All BTEC courses are coursework based, with students undertaking assessed units every 12 weeks or so, these are all graded, and the outcome is the sum of these assessments. BTEC courses suit students who prefer to ‚Äòchunk‚Äô their assessments rather than taking one or two summative exams at the end of the course which determine their final outcome. Compulsory subjects and options choices All students study the core subjects of English, Mathematics, Science, Arabic, Games and Moral, Social Cultural Studies. In addition to these core subjects, students also select four additional subjects from our extensive list of optional subjects. Each of these subjects is listed below with a brief outline of the course content and the method of assessment. Students who have been identified as requiring individual support will have their number of subjects reduced to allow for intervention. Arabic A What is involved? In Arabic, students will learn to speak, listen, read, write and communicate effectively in Arabic, as well as develop awareness and understanding of countries and communities where Arabic is spoken. How will I be assessed? This Edexcel International GCSE in Arabic (First Language) qualification comprises two external written assessed papers. Paper 1, written examination, 70% of the total International GCSE marks, 2 hours 15 minutes, which includes 10 minutes‚Äô recommended reading time. 70 marks Paper 2, written examination, produce two pieces of continuous writing. Students will Choose two titles from a choice of six 1 hour 30 minutes. 60 marks Grammatical usage which will be tested in Paper 1, Section 3 This course will also be supplemented with Ministry of Education assessments for Arab students. Arabic B What does it involve? Paper 1: Listening and Understanding in Arabic Students are assessed on their understanding of standard spoken Arabic in a variety of scenarios. Students will need to identify the overall message, key points, details and opinions, deduce meaning from a variety of spoken areas. The paper draws on vocabulary and structures across all themes. And students are presented with recorded scenarios involving one or more speakers in public and social settings, and the resources are authentic. Paper 2: Speaking in Arabic Students are assessed on their ability to communicate and interact through speaking in Arabic for different purposes in different settings. They will be assessed on 3 tasks: Task 1: Role play/ -Task 2 Picture-based task/Task 3: Conversation Paper 3: Reading and Understanding in Arabic Students are assessed on their understanding of written Arabic across a range of different types of texts. Scenarios in the texts are set either at home or, more frequently , in Arabic ‚Äìspeaking country, allowing students to develop appropriate cultural awareness and understanding. This paper draws on vocabulary and structures across all the themes. To be ready , there should be a variety of different contexts as appropriate to their age and level of understanding. Paper 4: Writing in Arabic The student are assessed on their ability to communicate effectively through writing in Arabic. Students need to: Communicate effectively in writing for a variety purpose across a range of specified contexts. Write short texts using simple sentences and familiar language accurately, make independent, creative and more complex use of words, translate sentences and short texts from English into the assessed language, apply grammatical rules Art & Design What does it involve? Alongside improving your practical expertise, you‚Äôll learn how to: Develop, refine and record your ideas Present a personal response that realises your intentions Improve your creative skills through the effective and safe use of media, materials, techniques, processes and technologies Successfully use visual language and the formal elements eg colour, line, form, shape, tone, texture Use drawing skills for different needs and purposes. Unit 1 ‚Äî Personal Portfolio in Art and Design (60% of total GCSE) Unit 2 ‚Äî Externally Set Assignment (40% of total GCSE) How will I be assessed? During the course you will produce a portfolio (60% of final mark). In Y11 at the start of term 2 you will begin an externally set assignment (40% of final mark). As part of the externally set assignment you will sit a 10 hour (across 2 days) supervised unaided practical exam. Business What is involved? Students apply their knowledge and understanding to different business contexts ranging from small enterprises to large multinationals and businesses operating in local, national and global contexts. Students develop an understanding of how these contexts impact on business behavior. Students will apply their knowledge and understanding to business decision making including: The interdependent nature of business activity, influences on business, business operations, finance, marketing and human resources, and how these interdependencies underpin business decision making How different business contexts affect business decisions The use and limitation of quantitative and qualitative data in making business decisions How will I be assessed? Paper 1: Influences of operations and human resources on business activity (50% of the IGCSE) Paper 2: Influences of marketing and finance on business activity (50% of the IGCSE) BTEC Level 2 Business What does it involve? Students should be interested in learning about the aspects of the business world around them, how businesses are set up and what makes a great entrepreneur. Through selected modules, students will be given a wider understanding of the large range of Business specialisms. How will I be assessed? Students will be assessed through well-defined assignments set from actual criteria, which is 100% coursework based. The assignments will be assessed through internal and external assessments on this 2 year course. The assessments will lead to grading of either Pass, Merit or Distinction, and students will have the opportunity to use differing mediums to demonstrate their creativity. Units 1 ‚Äì 3 are mandatory and the unit 5 is optional. Computer Science What does it involve? Data representation Communication & Internet technologies Hardwork & Software Security Ethics Algorithm design & problem solving Programming Databases How will I be assessed? Paper 1: Theory Concepts & Principles of Computer Science Paper 2: Problem Solving & Programming Knowledge and understanding of the key concepts and principles of computer science. length of exam: 1 hour 45mins. 75 marks 60% weighting. Knowledge and understanding of Programming concepts. 20 marks are on the pre-release programming task. Length of exam: 1 hour 45mins 50 marks. 40% weighting Design And Technology: Electronics What does it involve? Topics covered in this syllabus are: New and emerging technologies Energy Smart materials Mechanical devices Materials and their properties Professional designers Electronics How will I be assessed? At the end of the two year course students will need to be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of their chosen discipline through the completion of the following two: Component 1: 1 hour and 45 minute examination paper set and marked by Edexcel worth 100 marks which consists of: Section A Core: 40 marks and contains a mixture of different question styles, including open-response, graphical, calculation and extended-open-response questions. There will be 10 marks of calculation questions in Section A. and a subject specific element, all questions are compulsory Section B Electronics: 60 marks and contains a mixture of different question styles, including open-response, graphical, calculation and extended-open-response questions. There will be 5 marks of calculation questions Component 2: NEA ‚Äì Non Examined Assessment (Design and Make Contextual challenge) This unit is completed under internally timed controlled conditions. Students must complete a design and make activity. This activity is set by the exam board in the form of a contextual challenge on June 1st of Year 10 and summer homework is necessary. The Design and make contextual challenge is worth 100 marks and 50% of the final grade Design And Technology: Resistant Materials What does it involve? Topics covered in this syllabus are: New and emerging technologies Energy Smart materials Mechanical devices Materials and their properties Professional designers Timbers How will I be assessed? At the end of the two year course students will need to be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of their chosen discipline through the completion of the following two: Component 1: 1 hour and 45 minute examination paper set and marked by Edexcel worth 100 marks which consists of: Section A Core: 40 marks and contains a mixture of different question styles, including open- response, graphical, calculation and extended-open-response questions. There will be 10 marks of calculation questions in Section A. and a subject specific element, all questions are compulsory Section B Resistant Materials (Timbers): 60 marks and contains a mixture of different question styles, including open-response, graphical, calculation and extended-open-response questions. There will be 5 marks of calculation question Component 2: NEA ‚Äì Non Examined Assessment (Design and Make Contextual challenge) This unit is completed under internally timed controlled conditions. Students must complete a design and make activity. This activity is set by the exam board in the form of a contextual challenge on June 1st of Year 10 and summer homework is necessary The Design and make contextual challenge is worth 100 marks and 50% of the final grade Drama What is involved? The course will engage you through encouraging creativity, with a focus on practical work that reflects twenty-first century Theatre practise. You will develop your practical and analytical skills through the perspectives of a performer, director and designer of Theatre. How is it assessed? You will be assessed through three components. Component 1: Devising 40% (60 marks) Creating a devised performance from stimulus. (15 marks) Analyze and evaluate the devising process and performance (45 marks) Component 2: Performance from a text (20%) 48 marks Perform two key extracts from a performance text. Component 3: 40% (60 marks) Written examination on one complete performance text and live Theatre Evaluation. Economics What does it involve? The subject content looks at economic activity through the lens of the consumers, producers, and governments. Students will be covering economics in individual countries and the global economy. IGCSE Economics is designed as a two-year course for teaching in international schools such as Sunmarke. As students go through the course they are presented with opportunities to focus on real-world issues. Students should consider and reflect upon moral, ethical and sustainable issues that arise as a result of the impact of economic activity. How will I be assessed? Paper 1: Microeconomics & Business Economics Both 1 hour 30 minutes. Both have a 50% weighting of the qualification A mixture of multiple choice, short answer, data-response and open-ended questions Paper: Macroeconomics & the Global Economy English Language What does it involve? Students will study texts from: The contemporary non-fiction texts from Part 1 of the Pearson Edexcel International GCSE English Anthology. Any two poetry or prose texts from Part 2 of the Pearson Edexcel International GCSE English Anthology. A range of different text types so they can match the style and purpose for a creative piece and for their examination. How will I be assessed? Paper 1: Examination The contemporary non-fiction texts from Part 1 of the Pearson Edexcel International GCSE English Anthology. Weighting 60 % of the IGCSE ‚Äì 90 marks. Duration of paper ‚Äì 2 hours 15 mins Paper 3: Coursework portfolio Weighting 40% of the total IGCSE ‚Äì 60 marks. Assignment A: Poetry and prose texts ‚Äì one 30-mark essay question based on any two poetry or prose texts from Part 2 of the Pearson Edexcel International GCSE English Anthology, including a 6-mark commentary on why these texts were selected. Assignment B: Imaginative writing ‚Äì one 30-mark imaginative writing task. English Literature What does it involve? Study texts: Macbeth ‚Äì William Shakespeare An Inspector Calls ‚Äì J.B. Priestly Of Mice and Men ‚Äì John Steinbeck A collection of poetry from the Edexcel anthology How will I be assessed? Paper 1: Modern Prose and Poetry examination Weighting 60% of the IGCSE ‚Äì 90 marks Examination paper ‚Äì 2hrs Examination paper consists of 3 sections: Section A: Unseen Poetry, Section B: Poetry collection, Section C: Of Mice and Men Paper 3: Literary Heritage and Modern Drama coursework 40% of the IGCSE ‚Äì 60 marks. There are two coursework tasks worth 30 marks each. Assignment A: An Inspector Calls, Assignment B: Macbeth Food Preparation And Nutrition What does it involve? Year 10 focuses upon developing students‚Äô knowledge and understanding of the key topics, as outlined below, in readiness to undertake their Non-Exam Assessments in Year 11. The topics we will study are: Food, nutrition and health Food science Food safety Food choice Food provenance How will I be assessed? There are two Non-Exam Assessments (NEA) which are completed in year 11. The first, NEA1, is a food investigation task focusing on the Food Science topic, particularly nutrition and functions of ingredients. It is a written report (1,500-2,000 words) including photographic evidence of practical experiments. NEA1 is worth 15% of the overall grade. The second, NEA2, is a food preparation task focusing on practical skills as well as food safety, food choice and food provenance topics. Students will prepare, cook and present several dishes, to demonstrate complex cooking skills, before preparing a final menu of three dishes, which will be cooked within a three hour practical exam. The three dishes are presented in a ‚ÄòMasterChef‚Äô style where they are assessed by the teachers and the class. NEA2 is worth 35% of the overall grade. The written exam at the end of year 11 encompasses the five topics identified above. The exam consists of 20 multiple choice questions and five extended writing questions, each with a number of sub questions. Students will have 1 hour 45minutes to complete the exam and it is worth 50% of the overall grade. French What is involved? Students of our GCSE in French will learn to speak, listen, read, write and communicate effectively in French, as well as develop awareness and understanding of countries and communities where French is spoken. How will I be assessed? Unit 1: Listening and Understanding in French (25%) Students will be tested on their ability to understand spoken French. Testing is through a variety of tasks which require a response, written or non-verbal, to demonstrate understanding. Unit 2: Speaking in French (25%) Students must demonstrate the ability to use the French language for different purposes and in different settings and will be assessed in one final exam where they will have to respond to unseen questions, take part in role plays, respond to a stimulus and give a presentation. Unit 3: Reading and Understanding in French (25%) This unit draws on vocabulary and structures from across the three specified common topic areas. Students will be tested on their ability to understand written French. Testing is through a variety of tasks which require a response, written or non-verbal, to demonstrate understanding as well as translation tasks. Unit 4: Writing in French (25%) The student must complete two separate writing tasks as well as a translation task in the final exam. The writing tasks are taken from the three main themes of the specifications. Geography What does it involve? Students will study four interesting and challenging areas of study; Living with the Physical Environment Challenges in the Human Environment Geographical Applications Geographical Skills How will I be assessed? Paper 1 Living with the Physical Environment. Written paper ‚Äì 1 hour 30 minutes, 88 marks, 35% of GCSE. Paper 2 Challenges in the Human Enivronment. Written paper ‚Äì 1 hour 30 minutes, 88 marks, 35% of GCSE. Paper 3 Geographical Applications. Written paper ‚Äì 1 hour 15 minutes, 76 marks, 30% of GCSE. History What does it involve? Students will study four interesting and diverse topics in the form of Depth, Thematic and Period studies; British Thematic Study and Historic Enviroment: Medicine c. 1250 ‚Äì Present Period Study: Super power Relations and the Cold war, 1941 ‚Äì 91 British Depth Study Early Elizabeth England 1558 ‚Äì 88 Modern Depth Study: Weimas and Nazi Germany 1918 ‚Äì 39 How will I be assessed? Paper 1 30% Medicine Paper 2 40% Elizabeth & Cold War Paper 3 30% Weimar and Nazi Germany ICT What does it involve? There will be 6 topics to undertake over a 2 year programme. These are: Digital Devices Connectivity Operating Online Online Goods and Services Applying Information and Communication Technology Software Skills ‚Äì Office applications such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Access, as well as Web Development and Graphics software How will I be assessed? Paper 1 Written Exam 1 hour 30 min 50% Paper 2 Practical Exams (in an ICT labs using PCs) 3 hours 50% BTEC Level 2 Information Technology What does it involve? You will complete the following 4 units. Communicating in the IT industry ‚Äì using IT tools to communicate and exchange information. You will also look at the impacts of IT on individuals, communities and society. Working in the IT industry ‚Äì develops your knowledge of the available job roles involving professional IT and the characteristics employers demand in the IT industry. Website Development ‚Äì develop your skills and knowledge of how websites function. You will then design and create a multiple page website. Computer Graphics ‚Äì discuss the hardware and software to generate and manipulate computer generated images. You will then produce computer graphics using graphic software. How will I be assessed? The course is fully assessed through coursework (100%) and there is no examination. You will be assessed by completing set tasks for each unit, if you meet the criteria you will be awarded a grade for each unit. Each task may assess your knowledge in a variety of ways, such as: reports, presentation, blogs, vlogs, graphic products using range of software, a website using web editing software and practical tasks. Some units have a variety of ways in which you are assessed and others may have only one way. The BTEC Level 2 IT is graded at Pass, Merit, Distinction or Distinction*. The overall number of points you achieve determines your overall grade. Mathematics What does it involve? The course is split into four mathematical areas, each of which contributes towards the final award. Number Algebra Geometry Statistic How will I be assessed? IGCSE Mathematics is entirely assessed by written examination. The written examination will consist of two papers which are each worth one half of the final mark. Both papers are worth 50% each and are 2 hours each. Each exam is worth 100 marks. Both papers allow the use of a calculator. The papers can be taken at Higher Tier (Grades 9-3) or Foundation Tier (Grades 5-1). Students will be entered at the school‚Äôs discretion for the most appropriate tier for their ability Media Studies What does it involve? In media, you will get the opportunity to study a wide range of products, from magazines, TV shows, films, advertisements and social media. You will explore your creativity through planning, designing and producing magazine covers. Alongside this you will also engage with theory, analysing various different media texts in preparation for your exam. How will I be assessed? You are assessed through two written papers. Each worth 35% of your GCSE. You will then also produce a media product as coursework which is 30% of your GCSE. BTEC Creative Media Production What does it involve? Within Creative Media you will have the opportunity to investigate a wide range of media products such as podcasts, films, advertisements, and magazines. During each unit you will: Develop research skills into production processes and understanding your audiences Analyse existing products to understand how producers communicate meaning within a product Develop technical skills and produce media products for an intended audience Self-evaluate your progression and the quality of your product How will I be assessed? You will work in groups and independently across two years to complete 4 units: Digital Video Production Audio Podcast Production Advertising Production Pearson set Assignment- announced each year. For each unit you will be assessed across the set learning aims (A Research, B Developing your ideas and C Producing final outcomes) using the criteria of Pass, Merit and Distinction (being the highest available grade). The BTEC L2 is 100% coursework. Music What does it involve? Along with regular musical instrument rehearsals and composition projects, you will have the opportunity to study popular music, music for film and western classical music. How will I be assessed? This course is split into three components. Understanding music Performance Composition. At the end of the 2 year course, there will be a one and a half hour listening paper to be completed, analyzing music you have studied. You will be required to prepare two pieces of music for performance on any musical instrument of your choice. You will also prepare two compositions for your final assessment. Physical Education What does it involve? Subject content: Applied anatomy and physiology Movement analysis Physical training Use of data Sports psychology Socio-cultural influences Health, fitness and well-being Practical performance in sport How will I be assessed? Paper 1: (1 hour 15 minutes) 30% The human body and movement in physical activity and sport Paper 2: (1 hour 15 minutes) 30% Socio-cultural and well-being in physical activity and sport Non-exam assessment: 40% Practical performance in three physical activities as a performer (30%) Analysis of performance and evaluation to bring about improvement written coursework (10%) Psychology How will I be assessed? Subject content and assessment: This is a linear course and all examinations are sat at the end of the two years. Two written papers (100 marks) ‚Äì 50 % each of GCSE. Each exam is 1 hour and 45 minutes. Each exam covers 4 sections and will include multiple choice, short answer and extended essay questions (25 marks) How will I be assessed? Paper 1 (50%) ‚Äì Cognition and Behaviour Paper 2 (50%) ‚Äì Social context and behaviour 1. Memory 2. Perception 3. Development 4. Research methods 1. Social influence 2. Language, thought and communication 3. Brain and neuropsychology 4. Psychological Problems Science ‚Äì Double Award (Trilogy) What does it involve? You will study biology, chemistry and physics content and develop transferable practical skills. How will I be assessed? 6 x 1hr 15mins exams: Biology paper 1 & 2 Chemistry paper 1 & 2 Physics paper 1 & 2 Science ‚Äì Triple Award What does it involve? You will have extra science lessons in one of the option blocks and will study additional biology, chemistry and physics content and develop transferable practical skills. You will gain three separate GCSE qualifications in biology, chemistry and physics. How will I be assessed? (6 exams ‚Äì 1hr 45mins each) GCSE biology ‚Äì paper 1 & paper 2 (1hr 45mins each) GCSE chemistry ‚Äì paper 1 & paper 2 (1hr 45mins each) GCSE physics ‚Äì paper 1 & paper 2 (1hr 45mins each) Sociology What does it involve? Year 1 Year 2 Topic 1: Families and Households Topic 2: Education Topic 3: Research Methods Topic 4: Crime and Deviance Topic 5: Social Stratification Topic 6: Socialogical Theory and Methods How will I be assessed? This is over two papers at the end of the two year course. Each paper is worth 50% of the GCSE and involves a one hour 45 minutes written examination (100 marks) Paper 1: The sociology of families and education Paper 2: The sociology of crime and deviance and social stratification Spanish What is involved? Students of our GCSE in Spanish will learn to speak, listen, read, write and communicate effectively in Spanish, as well as develop awareness and understanding of countries and communities where Spanish is spoken. How will I be assessed? Unit 1: Listening and Understanding in Spanish (25%) Students will be tested on their ability to understand spoken Spanish. Testing is through a variety of tasks which require a response, written or non-verbal, to demonstrate understanding. Unit 2: Speaking in Spanish (25%) Students must demonstrate the ability to use the Spanish language for different purposes and in different settings and will be assessed in one final exam where they will have to respond to unseen questions, take part in role plays, respond to a stimulus and give a presentation. Unit 3: Reading and Understanding in Spanish (25%) This unit draws on vocabulary and structures from across the three specified common topic areas. Students will be tested on their ability to understand written Spanish. Testing is through a variety of tasks which require a response, written or non-verbal, to demonstrate understanding as well as translation tasks. Unit 4: Writing in Spanish (25%) The student must complete two separate writing tasks as well as a translation task in the final exam. The writing tasks are taken from the three main themes of the specifications Ministry Of Education KS4 Islamic A & B The Department‚Äôs Islamic Education Syllabus Sunmarke Islamic Education Syllabus is based on UAE recommended Curriculum of study and aims to develop in learners the following: An understanding of the concepts of commitment (Islam) and faith (Imaan) in a religious tradition. An awareness of how spiritual and moral issues (Ihsaan) permeate life experiences and the manner in which those may relate to students‚Äô own lives. A respect for the diverse range of religious and cultural traditions in the UAE and the wider world. A range of investigative, critical and moral thinking skills to enable them to make informed choices and decisions. Internal Assessment All students partake in a range of end of unit assessments covering: the meaning of Faith, Biographies of the Prophets and Muslim historical figures, Matters of daily ritual worship (Prayer, Charity, Fasting and Hajj), Islamic Ethics and Values and Quran Studies. View our Options & Information Booklet for full details on the GCSE and BTEC core subjects and option blocks.

title: Sports & PE at Secondary School in Sunmarke, Dubai
content: Sports & PE at Secondary School in Sunmarke, Dubai Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login About Principal‚Äôs Message Mission, Vision, Values A Positive Education School Leadership Academic Results Inspection Reports Our Achievements Sunmarke Alumni Wellbeing The Achievement Centre ‚Äì Inclusion Department Our Campus Learning Nursery Our Approach Enriched Learning EYFS Our Approach Early Years Curriculum Enriched Learning Primary Our Approach Primary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Student Council and Ambassadors Secondary Our Approach Secondary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Sunmarke Mini MBA Student Council and Ambassadors Sixth Form Our Approach A-Levels BTECs IB Diploma Programme (IBDP) Student Enrichment Coding CIVITAS Careers Counsellor Student Leadership Signature Programmes STEAM & Design Thinking Environment & Sustainability University & Career Readiness Programme Fortes Pro Sports Academy Positive Education Global Language Academy Financial Literacy Programme Enterprise & Mini-MBA Programme Communications, Media & the Performing Arts Programme Admissions Apply Online Schedule a Visit Tuition Fees Scholarships Re-enrol Online School Forms FAQs For Parents School Uniform School Timings Academic Calendar School Events Calendar Policies Transport Services Dining & Catering Sports Hub Parent Engagement Governance Committee Activities Sunmarke Free Extracurricular Activities (ECAs) Sunmarke Paid Extracurricular Activities Third-Party Paid Extracurricular Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login Sports & PE Learning > Secondary > Sports & PE Sports & PE A Celebration of Victory And Achievements On The Sporting Field Our students enjoy an extensive timetabled programme for PE including Health-related fitness, Swimming, Badminton, Table Tennis, Trampolining, Cricket, Rounders and Athletics. This offer is further enhanced by our Games Programme which gives students exposure to competitive team sports such as Football, Touch Rugby, Basketball, Netball, Volleyball, and Handball alongside further opportunities for developing health and fitness. Representing the school at any of these sports is a sought-after honour. We often have returning students coming back to school and speaking with pride about times they played in sports fixtures at Sunmarke. Specialist Team In addition to our committed PE staff, we enlist specialist coaching to strengthen the Games Programme and motivate students to engage in competitions at the local, regional, and national levels. Our teams, known as the Spartans, compete in events organised by DASSA and DAPSA, which are Dubai sports organisations, as well as the British Schools in the Middle East (BSME). World-class Facilities On-site, we have a full-sized and a 5-a-side Astroturf pitch, along with MUGA courts outdoors for multi-sport use. Indoors, we have two Multi-Purpose Sports halls, a dance studio, a gymnasium, a 25m swimming pool, and a learner swimming pool. Sunmarke's House System All students at Sunmarke school are members of one of our houses: Lions, Tigers, Leopards & Panthers. These houses continue to promote team spirit within our community. Throughout the school, students regularly participate in house competitions where they can earn flourish points, leading to both personal and group recognition. In secondary school, students are acknowledged for their contributions to their houses by taking part in house competitions, being an engaged learner, contributing to the community, and showing care and respect for others. Every week, a student of the week is chosen in each year group and celebrated for their efforts inside and outside of the classroom. This can include a weekly tea party with our Head of Secondary School, Mr Bell. To be invited for ‚ÄòTea with Mr. B‚Äô is a significant moment in a year in the life of our Sunmarke students. Students are encouraged to stay updated about upcoming house competitions through internal advertising and on our dedicated Instagram page @sunmarkehousessecondary . Our current house captains are: Leopards: Olivja, Jana Tigers: Marissa, Mia Lions: Vance, Karolina Panthers: Lavanya, Moazzam Visit Sunmarke Sports Hub Visit our Sports Hub here

title: Creative & Performing Arts - Sunmarke Secondary School, Dubai
content: Creative & Performing Arts - Sunmarke Secondary School, Dubai Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login About Principal‚Äôs Message Mission, Vision, Values A Positive Education School Leadership Academic Results Inspection Reports Our Achievements Sunmarke Alumni Wellbeing The Achievement Centre ‚Äì Inclusion Department Our Campus Learning Nursery Our Approach Enriched Learning EYFS Our Approach Early Years Curriculum Enriched Learning Primary Our Approach Primary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Student Council and Ambassadors Secondary Our Approach Secondary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Sunmarke Mini MBA Student Council and Ambassadors Sixth Form Our Approach A-Levels BTECs IB Diploma Programme (IBDP) Student Enrichment Coding CIVITAS Careers Counsellor Student Leadership Signature Programmes STEAM & Design Thinking Environment & Sustainability University & Career Readiness Programme Fortes Pro Sports Academy Positive Education Global Language Academy Financial Literacy Programme Enterprise & Mini-MBA Programme Communications, Media & the Performing Arts Programme Admissions Apply Online Schedule a Visit Tuition Fees Scholarships Re-enrol Online School Forms FAQs For Parents School Uniform School Timings Academic Calendar School Events Calendar Policies Transport Services Dining & Catering Sports Hub Parent Engagement Governance Committee Activities Sunmarke Free Extracurricular Activities (ECAs) Sunmarke Paid Extracurricular Activities Third-Party Paid Extracurricular Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login Creative & Performing Arts Learning > Secondary > Creative & Performing Arts Creative & Performing Arts Art-Infused Programmes That Bring Out The Best Creative Talents In Students Sunmarke is an international school where creative arts are given as equal importance as other subjects. Talented students blessed with imagination and creativity can express themselves through our deeply arts-infused programme in Music, Theatre, the Visual Arts and/or Dance and Media and Communication. The arts-infused programme in music, theatre, the visual arts, dance, and media and communication (where student reporters produce an online newspaper, podcasts, and blogs), develop skills in literacy, presentation, and collaboration. The ‚ÄòSunmarke School Tube‚Äô GCSE and Post-16 Media and Creative Art students have created the Sunmarke School Tube Channel. All videos are filmed and edited by our creative students. Enjoy and subscribe here . Sunmarke Shorts VLOG The Media and Communication focus is interesting as it allows interested students to join Sunmarke‚Äôs editorial team where they become student reporters, producing an online and physical newspaper, podcasts and blogs. These fun activities enhance their presentation, collaboration, and communication skills. Sunmarke offers students plenty of opportunities to tap into their creative side. Take a deeper look at our Creative Arts subjects below: Art Our Arts Department allows students to experiment in different disciplines such as fine art, digital art, textiles, sculpting, pottery and print-making. We have some outstanding wall art murals that Primary and Secondary school students collaborate on around the school. Music Sunmarke benefits from the Fortes‚Äô VIP Academy for Performing Arts and a team of professional music teachers who train students in varied musical instruments and skills. All students are encouraged to develop an appreciation of music. Every student learns an instrument of his or her choice and many develop mastery and choose to prepare for the Trinity/ABRSM music exams. Talented students are nurtured to consider music as a choice of higher study, while some choose to just have fun jamming in a band. Also, keep an eye out for the ‚Äò Lunchtime Pop-Up Series ‚Äò where our hottest musicians perform around school and delight all with their musical talents. Drama With inspirational drama and music teachers and an Auditorium, Black Box studio and several studios for the Performing Arts, Sunmarke provides students ample opportunities to contribute to various aspects of a theatrical production as performers or crew. Some of our most recent productions include We Will Rock You, Little Shop of Horrors, and The Wiz . Our Drama students also regularly enact plays and skits and participate in inter-school competitions.

Learning Opportunities To Develop Students' Personalities Beyond Academics Whether it is volunteering, trekking through the mountains overseas or speaking in front of a large crowd, students are given many opportunities to develop their personalities and explore their varied passions. Extra-Curricular Activities The extra-curricular activities at Sunmarke help channel students‚Äô energies into developing new skills. These school-run activities conducted by our teaching staff, vary each term and year depending on availability and staffing. Clubs are held before school, during lunch and after school. A typical range of clubs and activities include: Radio Podcast at Sunmarke Radio STEAM & The Environment Club The Great Sunmarke Bake-Off Cooking Club Yoga Choir Media, Marketing & eCommunications Club The World Scholars Cup ‚Äì Debating/Public Speaking Club Maths Enrichment Drama Club Design Club Art Club Computing & Robotics Badminton Football Fitness Volleyball Basketball The list above contains a range of the sports offered at Sunmarke. For more details on our sports programme please visit Public Speaking Sunmarke believes in giving its students a voice and a platform to express their opinions and ideas freely. Accordingly, we help them sharpen their public speaking skills through various programmes. With visits from the prestigious universities and being a host school for the world-renowned World Scholars Cup and TEDx talks, everyone has the chance to speak up and share their thoughts. The World Scholars Cup The World Scholars Cup is an international team academic programme, bringing together a community of future scholars and leaders from over 50 countries and diverse cultures, to discuss groundbreaking ideas relevant today and in the future. Our students have participated in the Dubai Rounds, the Global Rounds in Vietnam and successfully qualified and participated at the Tournament of Champions hosted at Yale University in the USA. Students enjoyed visiting other Ivy League Universities too. TEDx - Sunmarke An Official Host TedX ‚ÄòYou Are Here‚Äô As an official TEDx event host, Sunmarke hosts community-based discussions to spark ideas and connections. The first TEDx event held at Sunmarke School ‚Äì themed #YouAreHere ‚Äì was an epic occasion where 14 talented and poised Sunmarke speakers living in the ‚ÄúNow‚Äù shared their visions of the future. TedX ‚ÄòDream Big‚Äô In an evening that will be remembered for its profound inspiration and insightful dialogues, Sunmarke School successfully hosted the much-anticipated TEDxSunmarke event themed ‚ÄòDream Big‚Äô. The series of talks delivered by 8 students traversed a wide array of subjects, each narrating a different facet of personal ambitions, societal aspirations, and the vast potential of human creativity. Joshua Host - Year 12 Rodion Year 12 Sofia Year 12 Laila Year 13 Mohamad Year 12 Mira Year 8 Liam Year 7 Sandiaga Year 8 Mrs. Devika Mankani Divisional Head & Managing Director Regent International School & Chief Positive Psychologist of Fortes Education Residential Trips Students embark on many residential adventures in Secondary and Sixth Form. We have close partnerships with Camps International and Ecoventure ME that offer regional and international trips for students throughout the academic year. Sunmarke also offers The Duke of Edinburgh International Award (DofE International Award) which enriches our students‚Äô lives with practical experiences, life skills and allows them to discover their hidden talents and capabilities. The Duke Of Edinburgh Award The Duke of Edinburgh International Award, founded in 1956 by His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh is the world‚Äôs leading youth achievement award, bringing together experiences and life skills to equip young people for life. The concept of the Award is of individual challenge designed to encourage young people between 14 and 25 to develop into responsible, active citizens who will contribute towards society. What‚Äôs involved? The Award is voluntary, non-competitive, enjoyable and balanced, and requires students to expend effort over a period of time. There are three levels to the Award: Bronze, Silver and Gold. Young people design their own Award programme, set their own goals and record their own progress. They can choose four categories: Service, Physical Recreation or a Skills activity, or go on an Expedition. Here are some more details of each segment. Service The Award gives students the opportunity to give back to the community and make a real difference to the people or wildlife/animals, or to contribute to a good cause. It acquaints students with the joy of giving. Examples include: first aid, visiting and supporting people in need, volunteering at hospitals, sports coaching, charity work, etc. Physical Recreation Physical Recreation, both individually and within a team, is a fun and healthy way of developing a real sense of achievement outside the classroom, instilling enthusiasm and feeling of wellbeing. Examples include: Ball Sports, Athletics, Water Sports, Winter Sports, Martial Arts, Animal Sports, etc. Skill The Award encourages students to learn something new as a part of the process. Whether their interests lie in skiing or photography, the Award allows them to explore their passions. Examples include: Music, Arts and Crafts, Nature and the Environment, Communication, Games and Sports and related skills, etc. The Adventurous Journey The Adventurous Journey section is about undertaking a team journey or expedition. Participants plan, train for and undertake a journey with a purpose in an unfamiliar environment. Students spend 2 days and 1 night away completing around 12 hours of purposeful effort in total. Sunmarke Gavel (Toastmasters Club ) ‚ÄúIf you can speak, you can influence. If you can influence, you can change lives.‚Äù Toastmasters International, which has a legacy of 98 years will undoubtedly change your child‚Äôs life! At Sunmarke Gavel club, which is an affiliate of Toastmasters International, your child will get access to an International Acclaimed Public Speaking programme that will help your child get adequate public speaking skills for boosting their confidence and leadership. The program is open to students between the age of 12 to 18 years. Volunteering Opportunities Volunteering is one of the greatest gifts we can give others. Sunmarke‚Äôs student volunteers work closely with the Inclusion Department at the School to learn necessary skills to coach and assist their ‚Äúbuddies‚Äù during training sessions. This peer-coaching programme draws upon our school‚Äôs core values and Positive Education ethos whereby confidence, physical skills and social communication skills for our athletes are built upon.

Modules are taught by international professors at the University of Birmingham, Dubai, and in school by qualified Business and Economics Teachers. The Sunmarke mini-MBA is structured around practical themes. The real-world focus ensures we develop reflective leaders who can navigate the most challenging global trends and tensions. Throughout the programme students are also invited to lectures by guest speakers and visiting educational professors at the University of Birmingham, Dubai. Modules covered during the programme include: Economics Finance Marketing ‚ÄòMarketing to the GCC‚Äô Upon completion of the modules students then undertake a Business Project , which is designed to test their team-work, communication, leadership, negotiation, decision-making and risk-taking skills

Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login Our Approach Learning > Sixth Form > Our Approach Sixth Form School in Dubai Our Approach Achieving Outstanding Results With The Right Balance of Support, Inspiration And Challenge Sunmarke‚Äôs Sixth Form is imbued with the Positive Education approach, our dynamic and innovative Sixth Form curriculum is designed to meet the needs, talents and interest of our students, making them future-ready. Through our different pathways, we encourage students to ask questions about the world around them and think from multiple perspectives. We are unique in offering A-Levels, BTECs, and being an IB World School, we also offer the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme. Whether students choose the A-Level, BTEC; or the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme pathway, we inspire purpose and drive passion. Here at Sunmarke we care about the journey that students go on and the skills they develop along the way. Our students are not defined by grades, they are a collection of skills and interests that show their passion, and we want them to strive to be better learners to best prepare them for the path they choose after they graduate. Students will develop these skills through sessions run in form time on developing as a learner and preparing for higher education. While attending sessions for the latter, students will be exposed to resources that will help them explore their passions through reading, videos and courses outside of the curriculum that are now available online at the click of a button. Outside of the form room is where you will differ in terms of skills developed. The International Baccalaureate Programmes places more of an emphasis in developing a variety of skills due to the diverse subjects students have to take whereas A-Levels allow students to delve deeper into a smaller selection of subjects. Different still are BTEC qualifications which have no exams and will, therefore, develop your investigation and research skills as you look to answer your briefs. Leadership All students at Sunmarke‚Äôs Sixth Form are leaders and role models and they embrace this responsibility fully. These young leaders play a crucial role in the growth of the school and the community. Within their academics, students are provided options to lead their own learning such as through the Extended Project Qualification (EPQ), available to A Level and BTEC students or through various pieces of coursework, such as the Extended Essay and Reflective Project on the International Baccalaureate pathways. There are several opportunities for students to assume leadership roles, form their own extra-curricular activities and represent the school as Senior Prefects, Senior Student Leadership Team, House Captains and Subject Ambassadors. Thinking Skills Preparing students to flourish in an environment that encourages critical and independent thinking, Sunmarke‚Äôs Sixth Form is imbued with the Positive Education approach. Students are trained through the Theory of Knowledge (TOK) curriculum that motivates them to ask questions about the world around them and think from multiple perspectives. Digital Learning Sixth Form students model the use and integration of digital technologies throughout their curriculum. Many digital tools are available such as Questia School, an online library and UniFrog, a platform for search, shortlist and applying for university courses. Sixth Form Students are taught to be at ease with technology, but also encouraged to question its validity, reliability and responsibility in a modern world. Media literacy is given a lot of importance at Sunmarke as students prepare to navigate the world beyond the school. Please view our Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) Policy here . Social Responsibility Sunmarke Sixth Formers take the lead in service, learning and providing solutions while developing collaboration, leadership and social skills. There are structured programmes for students to follow such as CAS (Creativity, Activity, Service) and Service Learning that lists a set of objectives to be used as guidance. These are ‚Äòneed and solution-based‚Äô programmes where students can choose to give service to their peers, the school, the local community and even make a global difference. These programmes make them understand the difference they can make to the world while developing emotional intelligence. Global Outlook As an international school training students to excel globally, we foster an ethos of honesty, responsibility, tolerance and respect for others within the academic and Positive Education curriculum. Sixth Form students take a leading role in celebrations such as International Day by sharing their own cultures and traditions with the rest of the community. As a multi-pathway school, we aim to make our students global citizens. Key Stage 4 Options Booklet Sunmarke has designed the below listed booklet to give information to our students about the courses they could study in Years 10 and 11. These are useful as a guide to choose the right options and also serve as a reference point throughout the two year IGCSE, GCSE or BTEC Level 2 programmes. It gives a glimpse of the areas of study within each subject that can be used to support the teaching and learning. Sunmarke parents can view the PDF version of the Key Stage 4 Options Booklet from our parent communication portal, VLE. Click here to view the Key Stage 4 Options Booklet Sixth Form Options Booklet We have designed the below booklet to inform and support our students on the multiple pathways available to them. We are unique in offering A Levels, BTECs, and being an IB world school, we also offer the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme and the International Baccalaureate Career Related Programme. It is therefore, important to understand each one to make an informed decision. Sunmarke parents can view the PDF version of the Sixth Form Options Booklet from our parent communication portal, VLE. title: A-Levels Sixth Form Schools in Dubai | Sunmarke School Dubai
content: A-Levels Sixth Form Schools in Dubai | Sunmarke School Dubai Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login About Principal‚Äôs Message Mission, Vision, Values A Positive Education School Leadership Academic Results Inspection Reports Our Achievements Sunmarke Alumni Wellbeing The Achievement Centre ‚Äì Inclusion Department Our Campus Learning Nursery Our Approach Enriched Learning EYFS Our Approach Early Years Curriculum Enriched Learning Primary Our Approach Primary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Student Council and Ambassadors Secondary Our Approach Secondary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Sunmarke Mini MBA Student Council and Ambassadors Sixth Form Our Approach A-Levels BTECs IB Diploma Programme (IBDP) Student Enrichment Coding CIVITAS Careers Counsellor Student Leadership Signature Programmes STEAM & Design Thinking Environment & Sustainability University & Career Readiness Programme Fortes Pro Sports Academy Positive Education Global Language Academy Financial Literacy Programme Enterprise & Mini-MBA Programme Communications, Media & the Performing Arts Programme Admissions Apply Online Schedule a Visit Tuition Fees Scholarships Re-enrol Online School Forms FAQs For Parents School Uniform School Timings Academic Calendar School Events Calendar Policies Transport Services Dining & Catering Sports Hub Parent Engagement Governance Committee Activities Sunmarke Free Extracurricular Activities (ECAs) Sunmarke Paid Extracurricular Activities Third-Party Paid Extracurricular Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login A-Levels Learning > Sixth Form > A-Levels A-Levels An Internationally Recognised Qualification Focusing On Content-Driven Academic Subjects Why study A-Levels? Advanced Level qualifications (known as A-Levels) are individual subject based qualifications. They are one option available to students who are looking to study at university. With A-Levels being standalone qualifications, there is no requirement on subject combinations and students‚Äô only constraint is the combinations available within the school timetable. A-Levels are graded from A*-E. What does this Pathway look like? Students will usually take 3 or 4 A-Levels and this would be what universities would be looking for as offers are based mainly on 3 A-Level grades. If you are debating which subjects to choose, we recommend you start with 4 A-Levels so you can have a range to begin with which you can narrow down later. Students will receive 6 lessons per subject each week with most subjects being 100% examination-based. Subjects either fit into the category of modular A-Levels or linear A-Levels. In modular subjects, students will take up to three exams in Year 12 and up to three in Year 13 whereas, with linear A-Levels, students complete all exams at the end of Year 13. How does this Pathway lead to University? A-Levels are internationally recognised qualifications which will give you access to the most competitive universities worldwide. While taking A-Levels would give you the necessary prerequisites with regards to subjects, you may need to take further tests in English in order to study at universities where courses are delivered in English. In addition, students wishing to study certain subjects worldwide need to review the Mathematics requirements for entry into the university of their choice. What skills will I develop? Taking a combination of A-Levels will allow you to specialise in a particular area post 16 as opposed to waiting until you begin university. With few subjects having coursework components, there is a lot of focus on exam skills. However, there is the option of taking the Extended Project Qualification (EPQ) in order to develop your academic writing and research skills. Furthermore, the EPQ is a perfect opportunity for you to demonstrate and develop your interest in an area you want to go on to study at university; competitive universities are always looking for examples of students pursuing their academic passions outside of the classroom. Whether it be the other EPQ or another opportunity, we recommend you find an outlet to explore your passions through extra-curricular activities.

title: BTEC Programme - Business and Technology Education Council, Sunmarke
content: BTEC Programme - Business and Technology Education Council, Sunmarke Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login About Principal‚Äôs Message Mission, Vision, Values A Positive Education School Leadership Academic Results Inspection Reports Our Achievements Sunmarke Alumni Wellbeing The Achievement Centre ‚Äì Inclusion Department Our Campus Learning Nursery Our Approach Enriched Learning EYFS Our Approach Early Years Curriculum Enriched Learning Primary Our Approach Primary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Student Council and Ambassadors Secondary Our Approach Secondary Curriculum Sports & PE Creative & Performing Arts Enriched Learning Coding Sunmarke Mini MBA Student Council and Ambassadors Sixth Form Our Approach A-Levels BTECs IB Diploma Programme (IBDP) Student Enrichment Coding CIVITAS Careers Counsellor Student Leadership Signature Programmes STEAM & Design Thinking Environment & Sustainability University & Career Readiness Programme Fortes Pro Sports Academy Positive Education Global Language Academy Financial Literacy Programme Enterprise & Mini-MBA Programme Communications, Media & the Performing Arts Programme Admissions Apply Online Schedule a Visit Tuition Fees Scholarships Re-enrol Online School Forms FAQs For Parents School Uniform School Timings Academic Calendar School Events Calendar Policies Transport Services Dining & Catering Sports Hub Parent Engagement Governance Committee Activities Sunmarke Free Extracurricular Activities (ECAs) Sunmarke Paid Extracurricular Activities Third-Party Paid Extracurricular Activities News & Events Weekly Buzz Blog Press Podcasts Contact Us Work With Us Apply Visit Enquire VLE Login BTECs Learning > Sixth Form > BTECs BTECs A Dynamic BTEC Programme Helping Students Develop Vocational Skills To Move To University Or Into Direct Employment What are BTECs? Short for Business and Technology Education Council, BTECs are a practical-based, vocational qualification which offers the same equivalence to A-Levels when converted into UCAS points. Many industry sectors have a set of National Occupational Standards that professionals must follow. The learning content of BTECs is built around these National Occupational Standards, which is why BTECs are recognised as valuable qualifications. They provide the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in a field or subject and are an excellent alternative to the more theory focused A-Levels or subjects on the IB Diploma Programme. What does this Pathway look like? BTECs are taught through application with students often going on educational visits and meeting industry specialists as well as completing one week of work experience in Year 12. Assessments are via regular coursework and projects throughout the 2-year course. If you know you don‚Äôt excel in exam conditions, BTECs can relieve this pressure, spreading out the work that dictates your final grade as 100% of your final grade will come from these coursework components. Students are able to take a combination of BTECs and A-Levels in order to have a balance between hands on learning whilst also taking more traditional subjects. How does this Pathway lead to University? BTECs are equivalent to A-Levels in terms of applications to universities. However, there are some universities which don‚Äôt accept these qualifications so you would need to research the different countries you would like to apply for in order to ensure you meet the admissions criteria for your desired destination. What skills will I develop? BTECs truly prepare students for the real world, offering them practical skills to be successful in the industry of their choosing. If you enjoy practical learning and want to study a specialised range of subjects, BTECs are the perfect option for you. Within each subject, more technical skills are developed; for example, we are very proud of our BTEC Media courses that allow students to create using hi-tech equipment as students learn how to get the most out of this technology.

Diploma Programme (IBDP) Supporting Students To Compete At The Global Level The mission of the International Baccalaureate Organisation (IBO)‚Äôs programmes is to ‚Äúdevelop inquiring, knowledgeable and caring young people who help to create a better and more peaceful world through education that builds intercultural understanding and respect.‚Äù Sunmarke offers the IB Diploma Programme as this mission aligns with our own to ‚ÄúNurture the next generation of change-makers for a better tomorrow.‚Äù Through its exceptional academic and non-academic initiatives, our school grooms our students to use their education to positively influence their communities. Find out more about the details of the IB Diploma Programme at Sunmarke. What is the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme? The International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme (IBDP) is a holistic programme which gives you a broad post 16 education whilst also allowing you to specialise in three subjects. You will take three Standard Level subjects and three Higher Level subjects as well as the Extended Essay, Theory of Knowledge and the Creativity, Activity and Service Programme (CAS). Each subject is graded from 1-7 with the diploma core (Theory of Knowledge and Extended Essay) giving 3 more points depending on the combination of grades in these components. Students must achieve a minimum total of 24 points to pass the Diploma Programme. What does this Pathway look like? Each week you will receive lessons in your 6 subjects (typically 4 lessons for higher level and 3 for standard level) as well as lessons in Theory of Knowledge (TOK). You will also receive sessions to develop writing and research skills needed for the Extended Essay. This is a piece of academic writing where you choose the subject, topic and research question to produce an answer in a 4,000 word research report. The CAS programme is a non-graded component which encourages students to set objectives in creative, active and service experiences outside of the classroom. Each subject has a coursework component worth at least 20% meaning the whole grade does not rest on the final exams. How does this Pathway lead to University? An internationally recognised qualification, the IBDP will give you access to the most competitive universities worldwide. With the DP developing more than just subject knowledge, universities see it as a perfect higher education preparation programme. As all students study English Language and Literature, you will meet the language requirement of most universities that deliver courses in English. The IBDP programme also continues a student‚Äôs study in Mathematics. Students completing the IBDP programme continue to study Mathematics and English throughout their Secondary education and are then able to demonstrate 4 years of study in Mathematics and English during the application process. The IB Diploma, due to its holistic nature and its requirements, is highly valued by universities worldwide. What skills will I develop? Through coursework components, the Extended Essay and Theory of Knowledge, you will learn to think critically, write well constructed, balanced arguments and write using an academic structure. The CAS programme develops skills to ensure you are a well-rounded student who has lots of experiences beyond the classroom to make you really stand out in university applications and interviews. IB Diploma Programme courses options on offer at Sunmarke: English Language & Literature Environmental Systems and Societies French Spanish Psychology Business Management Visual Arts Economics Physics Biology Chemistry Maths: Analysis & Approaches Maths: Application & Interpretation Film ¬© International Baccalaureate Organization 2018 At the core of the IB Programmes is a focus on teaching and learning, and the IB Learner Profile. The IB Learner Profile is a set of traits which the IB believes students must develop to meet the mission‚Äôs long-term goal. Throughout the two years of the programme, teachers will promote these attributes in lessons to help students become better learners which will enhance their academic journey and prepare them to be more independent after graduating from school. Below are the 10 traits that make up the IB Learner Profile.

We believe each student possesses unique strengths and capabilities and it is our responsibility to provide opportunities for personal growth and empowerment by enabling individuals to make meaningful contributions to Civitas societies. Counsellor Careers Counsellor Specialist Staff To Guide and Inspire Students To Find The Right Career Pathway Specialist One-to-One Support Sunmarke has two full-time Careers Counsellors, who, along with Form Tutors and the Head of 6 th Form, advise students on their higher education and career path. Students works closely with these experts and parents are always welcome to speak to our Careers and University team to find a pathway suitable for their child. Through conversations and research, students can find their calling and a pathway of study that excites and enthuses. Read below to see the different opportunities and platforms we use in order to help students get excited about education outside of the Sunmarke classrooms. UNIFROG Unifrog is the career and university platform that is used at Sunmarke School. It‚Äôs an impartial, user-friendly platform that helps students to research their future pathways. It contains a repository of career lessons, information on pathways, universities around the world, CV builder, personality tests, and links to MOOCs (online courses). Unifrog is useful for students in their last four years of study but can be accessed and used by all in Secondary. Students can use the platform to start to explore the different post 18 pathways and the application process for their chosen route. Careers lessons in Y12 focus on psychometric testing, university and career research and to start working on application requirements such as personal statements and US university essays. We encourage all families to explore this platform together as early as possible in order to start the conversation as to where a student may study as well as what the course requirements are in order to make sure the right combination of subjects are being chosen post 16. There are many factors that go into shortlisting universities such as location, size, tuition fees or university housing to name just a few; with all this choice, it is important to narrow down to specific countries in Year 12 so the application process is not overwhelming in Year 13. Students work one-on-one with the university careers counsellors who assist and guide students through every step of the application process. University Destinations Sunmarke students achieve their first choice university destinations which has included UK Russel Group schools, and top Worldwide destinations such as the Imperial College London, NYU, University of Amsterdam, Bocconi, Carnegie Mellon, UCLA, UC San Diego, Georgia Tech, The University of Toronto, McGill and University of Edinburgh. For a full list of our destinations, click here . Offline University Guidance Parents are invited to join our ‚ÄòSunRise Sessions‚Äô where they learn about different aspects of applying to universities around the world and get informed about the procedures and pathways. Our tailored programme of learning includes researching courses, writing personal statements, practising for aptitude tests and interviews, holding mock interviews and completing applications. We also host admissions teams from leading universities from around the world each year, giving students a unique opportunity to find out more about their courses and expectations. If Oxford, Cambridge or the American Ivy Leagues are in your sights, we have a specialist team to advise you. Think & Thrive Entrepreneur Series ‚ÄòThink & Thrive‚Äô is Sunmarke‚Äôs very own Speaker Series linking innovators and business leaders in the region with savvy students. A student moderated event, ‚ÄòThink & Thrive‚Äô allows them to interact with guests in a unique, studio-style setting. Guest speakers have included: Ishwar Chugani, CEO and Managing Director of Giordana Fashions Virgin Radio DJ Brent Black Sonia Weymuller, Managing Partner of Venture Souq Zubin Chiba, Corporate Finance Leader and Partner ‚Äì PwC Middle East Maaz Sheikh ‚Äì CEO of Starz Play Nida Raza ‚Äì Senior Director and Head of Global Capital Markets at JLL Manish Hira ‚Äì Managing Director, Hira Industries Balki Radhakrishnan, Vice President and Managing Director ‚Äì General Mills AMEA Dr Marc Sinclair, Head of Orthopaedics ‚Äì King‚Äôs College Hospital Cristina de Torres, Partner ‚Äì PwC Middle East Francois Oberholzer, CFO ‚Äì Flydubai Dr Ryan Penny ‚Äì Therapeutic Lifestyle Consultant Eleni Giokos ‚Äì CNN Correspondent Rasna Al Khamis ‚Äì Chief Marketing Officer of Emirates Nature Kitchen Lachlan ‚Äì RJ at LUV 107.1 and Deputy Program Director / Announcer at TALK 100.3 Maitha Alawadi ‚Äì Scriptwriter and Director Malika Singh ‚Äì Producer Watch one of our Think & Thrive highlights video below: Workplace Internships At Sunmarke Academic knowledge complemented by real-world experience is most effective while preparing students for a great career. At Sunmarke, we encourage our students in Year 10 and 12 to actively participate in work experience programmes during the final week of Term 3. For our Year 12 IBCP students, work experience is an integral part of their curriculum. We work with our parent community and other links to companies to create meaningful experiences for students in a variety of sectors. Companies who participate in our Workplace Internships programme are listed below. Banking : ‚Äì Citibank Investment Banking: ‚Äì JP Morgan Chase ‚Äì Goldman Sachs Consulting: ‚Äì Deloitte ‚Äì McKinsey & Company ‚Äì Delta Partners Business Consultancy ‚Äì PWC Healthcare: ‚Äì Saudi German Hospital ‚Äì New York Dental Studio ‚Äì Kings College Hospital ‚Äì Emirates Specialty Hospital ‚Äì Takeda Pharmaceuticals Hotels & Hospitality: ‚Äì Jumeirah Group ‚Äì Atlantis Hotel ‚Äì Grand Hyatt Creek ‚Äì Zabeel House Hotel ‚Äì Pullman Hotel ‚Äì Business Bay ‚Äì Movenpick JLT Construction: ‚Äì GBH Construction ‚Äì Caterpillar Health & Fitness: ‚Äì Johnson & Johnson ‚Äì Tribe Fit ‚Äì Emirates Golf Club ‚Äì Sustainable City Equestrian Club Technology: ‚Äì IBM ‚Äì Microsoft Finance ‚Äì Help AG Dubai ‚Äì Vision Valley ‚Äì Finastra ‚Äì Logitech ‚Äì FEDS ‚Äì Drones Venture Capital: ‚Äì LAZARD Fund Managers ‚Äì Detec Space Contracting E- Commerce : ‚Äì Lightspeed Online Recruitment: ‚Äì Bayt Retail: ‚Äì Aurea Puig Fashion ‚Äì Guiseppe Zannotti Real Estate: ‚Äì Tabani Real Estate ‚Äì MAG Properties ‚Äì Time Properties Law: ‚Äì Hadef & Partners Aviation: ‚Äì Fly Dubai Energy/ Engineering: ‚Äì SVS Energi ‚Äì Hira Industries Automotive: ‚Äì Pro Fix International ‚Äì Exotic Cars ‚Äì Super Fix Garage Media/TV/ Press/ Production: ‚Äì First and Ten ‚Äì E7awi ‚Äì Base Films Veterinary Services : ‚Äì Paws and Relax ‚Äì Umm Sequim Vet Center ‚Äì European Veterinary Center ‚Äì Pawsome Pets Career Links Careers education, information, advice and guidance is an essential part of the support we offer to students. As options for young people become more varied and complex, it is vital that we support them with knowledge and skills they need to make informed choices. As a result, the careers guidance has a whole-school remit designed to complement the rest of the school curriculum. This policy sets out how career activities are delivered at school and what stakeholders can expect. Aims and Objectives The careers guidance aims to: Encourage students to be ambitious, broaden their horizons and explore their own aspirations throughout their life at school Ensure students‚Äô readiness to take their next step in their learning or career Help students to understand the changing world of work Facilitate meaningful encounters with potential employers Support positive transitions Post-16 and Post-18 Enable students to develop research skills Help them to develop the skills, attitudes and qualities to make a successful transition into the world of work Encourage participation in continued learning, including further and higher education Support inclusion, challenging stereotyping and promoting equality of opportunity Contribute to strategies for raising achievement, particularly by increasing motivation

Design Thinking STEAM & Design Thinking Programme Future-Ready Learning in Our SPACE-X Innovation Lab Programme Overview At Sunmarke School, the STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Mathematics) Signature Programme transforms students into inventors, engineers, designers, and problem-solvers through immersive, real-world learning. Anchored in our state-of-the-art SPACE-X Innovation and Design Thinking Lab, the programme encourages experimentation, collaboration, and creativity from EYFS to Year 11. Who It‚Äôs For All students from EYFS through Year 11 ‚Äî regardless of prior technical knowledge. Support is available for all learning needs, including Students of Determination. Learning Journey EYFS & KS1 (Ages 3‚Äì7): Discovery-based play, early coding, foundational design skills KS2 (Ages 7‚Äì11): Engineering challenges, collaborative builds, STEAM fairs KS3‚ÄìKS4 (Ages 11‚Äì16): Advanced prototyping, mechanical systems, venture incubation, AI programming What Makes It Unique Integration of Stanford Design Thinking methodology Dedicated SPACE-X Lab with 3D printers, robotics, electronics, and fabrication zones Hands-on prototyping, AI, and entrepreneurial ventures Industry mentorship and venture incubators Seamless integration with subjects like English, Business, Maths, and Art Facilities & Resources SPACE-X Innovation Lab with professional-grade tools Design Thinking Labs Digital media and design studios Electronics and robotics workstations Maker spaces and 3D fabrication labs Signature Opportunities Shark Tank-style pitch competitions Real-world product launches through the Venture Incubator Industry expert mentorship and career shadowing STEAM showcases and student exhibitions Student Outcomes Readiness for careers in innovation, tech, engineering, design, and entrepreneurship Pathways to GCSE, A-Level, IB, and BTEC qualifications in relevant fields Enhanced creativity, analytical thinking, and collaboration skills Next Steps Book a lab tour, attend our annual STEAM showcase, or speak to our coordinators to explore how your child can engage with innovation at every stage of their learning. Programmes > Environment & Sustainability Environment & Sustainability Programme Nurturing Tomorrow's Environmental Changemakers Through Forest School Programme Overview Preparing Global Environmental Leaders With climate change at the forefront of global challenges, Sunmarke‚Äôs Environment & Sustainability Programme nurtures a deep connection with nature while developing scientific knowledge, eco-leadership, and sustainability values. Our immersive outdoor learning environments ‚Äî including the Forest School, Zen Garden, Vegetable Garden, and Hydroponic Farming Lab ‚Äî make sustainability an everyday experience. Who It‚Äôs For All students from EYFS to Year 13. The programme is cross-disciplinary and fully integrated into academic and co-curricular learning. Learning Journey EYFS: Sensory play, simple conservation habits, nature appreciation Primary: Ecosystem studies, organic gardening, biodegradable product design Secondary: Environmental research, global climate advocacy, sustainability leadership Natural Learning Environments Forest Garden: Guided biodiversity exploration Vegetable Garden: Organic farming and seasonal harvesting Zen Garden: Mindfulness and reflection in nature Hydroponic Lab: Soil-free, water-conserving agriculture using high-tech systems Signature Programme Elements Climate-focused STEM projects and eco-entrepreneurship Desert, beach, and neighbourhood clean-up drives Biodiversity and conservation field studies Student-led petitions and environmental campaigns Integration of UN Sustainable Development Goals TASS ( The Alliance for Sustainable Schools) ‚Äì empowering our students to lead sustainable change through global collaboration and impactful green initiatives. Wellbeing Through Nature Stress reduction, focus, creativity, and resilience through outdoor learning Character strengths like empathy, perseverance, and responsibility nurtured in real-world contexts Curriculum Integration Science: Ecology, conservation biology, climate systems Technology: Environmental monitoring, VR tools, climate modelling Engineering: Renewable energy, sustainable design Math: Statistical analysis and modelling of environmental data Languages: Cultural approaches to conservation (Mandarin, Hindi, French) Facilities & Resources Hydroponic stations, composting units, environmental sensors Outdoor classrooms and natural laboratories Community garden and student-led sustainability zones such as Forest School and Zen Garden. Pathways & Progression GCSE, A-Level, BTEC and IB Environmental Systems & Societies Career preparation in sustainability, conservation, and environmental policy Strong university placement record in environmental and science fields Next Steps Join a Forest School session, explore the Hydroponic Lab, or attend our student-led Sustainability Showcase to witness the programme in action.
